They have no answer when you ask them how western Europe could
possibly m& be defended without German participation, they concede
that west Germans should have the right and the capacity to defend them¬
selves against an attack from the east. But like the French* the Italians
find it very hard to take that final step and agree to put guns once again
in the hands of Germans.
They say; We know the Germans, we had them in our country fro a
long time in world War II* first as allies of Fascist Italy and then as
enemies of liberated Italy. There has been too little time for us to
forget what they did and to get around to a readiness to trust them. And
if you have ever visited the urdeatine caves at the south edge of Home*
where the German SS slaughtered more than 300 Italian civilians in March
of 1944, you can appreciate this feeling.
It has not been 91 very pleasant to write this particular Letter from
Italy. But* as I said earlier* this growing concern of Italian democrats
about the course of American foreign policy is striking and impressive for
a newly-arrived American reporter. And let me repeat! these people are
Italian democrats, representing the middle road partiesj the kind of
people on whom the ho pee for survival and strengthening of the Italian
democracy must rest. They are our friends. They have supported American
policies in the past and would like to do so in the future.
It would be altogether too simple an explanation to say that these
Italians have been influenced by Communist propaganda. And I believe
that their beliefs are held widely enough in this country so that they
cannot be dismissed as unimportant. Hence, X thought I would make of
this letter from Italy a report on how at least a part of Italy — an
important Ml§p part — looks at America.
